conclusion: Understand the geometry of the hemispherical glass brick.
A beam of parallel light is directed vertically towards the lower surface of the glass brick.
Light will refract as it enters and exits the glass brick.
The light will be emitted if it does not exceed the critical angle for total internal reflection.
Critical angle is given by sin(theta_c) = 1/n, where n is the refractive index.
Light refracts at the lower surface according to Snell's Law.
Light exits the glass brick at the upper surface, refracting again.
Maximum width of the incident light beam is determined by the point where light grazes the edge of the hemisphere.
Width of the incident light beam is the chord length at the critical angle.
Chord length L is calculated using L = 2R sin(theta_c).
Substitute sin(theta_c) = 1/n into the formula: L = 2R/n.
Maximum width of the incident light beam on AB is 2R/n.
